column4: Description
Supported
Not supported.
Indicates an instruction syntax is not encodable in 64-bit mode (it may represent part of a sequence of valid instructions in other modes).
Indicates the REX prefix does not affect the legacy instruction in 64-bit mode.
Indicates the opcode is treated as a new instruction in 64-bit mode.

Indicates an instruction syntax that requires an address override prefix in 64-bit mode and is not supported. Using an address override prefix in 64-bit mode may result in model-specific execution behavior
Description
Supported.
Not supported.
Indicates an Intel 64 instruction mnemonics/syntax that is not encodable
Symbol
ST(i)
column5: The i th element from the top of the FPU register stack (i ← 0 through 7).

column4: vm32{x,y,z}
column5: A vector array of memory operands specified using VSIB memory addressing. The
array of memory addresses are specified using a common base register, a constant scale factor,
and a vector index register with individual elements of 32-bit index value in an XMM register (vm32x), a YMM register (vm32y) or a ZMM register (vm32z).

column4: vm64{x,y,z}
column5: A vector array of memory operands specified using VSIB memory addressing. The array of memory addresses are specified using a common base register, a constant scale factor, and a vector index register with individual elements of 64-bit index value in an XMM register (vm64x), a YMM register (vm64y) or a ZMM register (vm64z).

A mask register used as instruction writemask for instructions that do not allow zeroing-masking but support merging-masking. This corresponds to instructions that require the value of the aaa field to be different than 0 (e.g., gather) and store-type instructions which allow only merging-masking.

A mask register used as instruction writemask. The 64-bit k registers are: k1 through k7. Writemask specification is available exclusively via EVEX prefix. The masking can either be done as a merging masking, where the old values are preserved for masked out elements or as a zeroing masking. The type of masking is determined by using the EVEX.z bit.

column3: 32-bit, 48-bit, or 80-bit pointer, depending on operand-size attribute.
Quadword MMX technology register (for example: mm0).
Scalar element of a 128-bit double-precision floating data.
Scalar element of a 128-bit single-precision floating data.
Word, doubleword or quadword (in 64-bit mode), depending on operand-size attribute.
dq or qq based on the operand-size attribute.
Doubleword or quadword (in 64-bit mode), depending on operand-size attribute.
Word for 16-bit operand-size or doubleword for 32 or 64-bit operand-size.

column4: Example

column3: Form of register identifier that indicates 16 or 32-bit widths are applicable
column4: eAX indicates that the AX register is used when the operand-size attribute is 16 and the EAX register is used when the operand-size attribute is 32

column3: Form of register identifier that indicates 16, 32 or 64-bit widths are applicable
column4: rAX can indicate AX, EAX or RAX.

column3: Indicates that the Rex.B bit is used to modify the register specified in the reg field of the opcode
column4: rCX/r9 is used to indicate that the register could either be rCX or r9

column3: Bits 5, 4, and 3 of ModR/M byte used as an opcode extension (refer to Section A.4, “Opcode Extensions For One-Byte And Two-byte Opcodes”).
Use the 0F0B opcode (UD2 instruction), the 0FB9H opcode (UD1 instruction), or the 0FFFH opcode (UD0 instruction) when deliberately trying to generate an invalid opcode exception (#UD).

Some instructions use the same two-byte opcode. If the instruction has variations, or the opcode represents different instructions, the ModR/M byte will be used to differentiate the instruction. For the value of the ModR/M byte needed to decode the instruction, see Table A-6.
The instruction is invalid or not encodable in 64-bit mode. 40 through 4F (single-byte INC and DEC) are REX prefix combinations when in 64-bit mode (use FE/FF Grp 4 and 5 for INC and DEC).
Instruction is only available when in 64-bit mode.
When in 64-bit mode, instruction defaults to 64-bit operand size and cannot encode 32-bit operand size.
The operand size is forced to a 64-bit operand size when in 64-bit mode (prefixes that change operand size are ignored for this instruction in 64-bit mode).
VEX form only exists. There is no legacy SSE form of the instruction. For Integer GPR instructions it means VEX prefix required.
VEX128 & SSE forms only exist (no VEX256), when can’t be inferred from the data size
The ModR/M byte follows the opcode to specify a word or doubleword operand
The reg field of the ModR/M byte selects a general-purpose register
Immediate data is encoded in the subsequent byte of the instruction.

column4: Meaning
General-register specifier (see Table B-4 or B-5)
Specifies if data is byte or full-sized, where full-sized is 16 or 32 bits (see Table B-6)
Specifies sign extension of an immediate field (see Table B-7)
Segment register specifier for CS, SS, DS, ES (see Table B-8)
Segment register specifier for CS, SS, DS, ES, FS, GS (see Table B-8)
Specifies a special-purpose (control or debug) register (see Table B-9)
For conditional instructions, specifies a condition asserted or negated (see Table B-12)
Specifies direction of data operation (see Table B-11)1

column3: Instruction modifies flag (either sets or resets depending on operands).
Instruction's effect on flag is undefined.
Instruction restores prior value of flag.

column1: 1-byte primary opcodes => the tttn field is located in bits 3, 2, 1, and 0 of the opcode byte.
2-byte primary opcodes => the tttn field is located in bits 3, 2, 1, and 0 of the second opcode byte.
